Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: Sample Size Bias in Judgments of Averages

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on a phenomenon of quantitative cognition called sample size bias, which occurs when people make judgments of averages. Specifically, as the number of items in a set increases, people judge the average to be greater. For example, the average of a set of ten numbers is judged to be greater than the average of five numbers -- even when the two sets have the same average. But sample size bias also occurs for conceptual dimensions such as risk. For example, the average heart-attack risk of ten people is judged to be greater than the average heart-attack risk of five people. The core of this project is a series of empirical studies in which a cross-section of people judge several kinds of averages under a variety of conditions. These studies have two purposes. The first is to test a theory that assumes that set size automatically activates an analog representation of magnitude in the brain, which in turn affects the representation and judgment of the average. The second is to see whether the sample size bias affects other kinds of judgments about averages, including judgments about one's own experience and behavior.

This work is important for a number of reasons. First, the theory being tested has the potential to help integrate sample size bias with similar phenomena from distinct areas of research including judgment and decision making, perception, and the neuroscience of quantitative cognition. Second, this research will help identify real-world contexts in which people's judgments of averages are likely to reflect sample size bias. For example, surveys often ask people to make judgments about what is average or typical for them or their peers (e.g., the average number of times they use health services per year). It is important to know whether such judgments are likely to be systematically biased and how such biases might be corrected. Finally, this project will provide high quality research training and experience to a diverse group of undergraduate and master's-level students at California State University, Fresno and Appalachian State University. This in turn will prepare them to succeed in doctoral studies in any of a variety of areas, cognitive and social psychology, judgment and decision making, and management science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past few decades, cognitive psychologists have identified numerous biases that plague human judgment and decision making. For example, many judgments exhibit an availability bias; they are overly influenced by information comes most easily to mind. The present research focused on a newly discovered cognitive bias that we call sample size bias. This occurs when people make judgments about the average of a group, such as the average friendliness of a group of people, the average size of a group of objects, the average quality of a group of consumer products, or the average duration of a group of events. What we have found is that as the number of individuals in the group increases, people’s judgments about the average of the group increase as well. For example, a set of nine squares shown on a computer screen are judged to be larger on average than a set of six squares, which are judged to be larger on average than a set of three squares—even when the average size of the squares is exactly the same.

The purpose of the present research was to show how this sample size bias applies to many different kinds of judgments, to show how it might help to explain other puzzling phenomena related to human judgment, and to try to understand why it occurs. Another purpose was to provide training in scientific psychological research to a larger and diverse group of students at California State University, Fresno—with the hope of sending some of them on to become researchers themselves.

Five master’s students and seventeen undergraduate students ended up being directly involved in the research. During the grant period we conducted close to twenty new studies, submitted three manuscripts to peer-reviewed scientific journals (one of which has been published so far), and made ten presentations at professional conferences.

Our main scientific accomplishment was to demonstrate the sample size bias in number of situations. As described previously, we showed that the average of a larger group of squares is estimated to be greater than the average of a smaller group of squares. We also conducted studies to show that the average price of a larger group of products is estimated to be greater than the average prices of a smaller group of products, the average attractiveness and weight of a group of people is judged to be greater than the average attractiveness and weight of a smaller group of people, and the average duration of a larger group of events is estimated to be longer than the average duration of a smaller group of events.

We were also able to show that the sample size bias is likely to be responsible for some other interesting judgment phenomena. For example, some previous research has shown that people evaluate products such as sofas more positively when they are in a group than when they are on their own. Some of our studies went beyond this to show that larger groups of products are evaluated more positively than smaller groups of products—suggesting that this phenomenon is another example of the sample size bias. Similarly, some recent research has shown that groups of people are rated as more attractive than the individuals who make up those groups. This has been called the “cheerleader effect.” Again, some of our studies went beyond this to show that ratings of the average attractiveness of larger groups are greater than ratings of the average attractiveness smaller groups—suggesting that this phenomenon too is another example of the sample size bias.
